item.title: Chasing Tax Cuts, Trump and Republicans Want to Make States Pay
item.description: G.O.P. leaders are exploring cuts to federal aid, leaving some states fearful that their budgets cannot absorb billions of dollars in new costs.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:description: President Trump and his Republican allies in Congress are coalescing around a new strategy: forcing cash-strapped states to pick up more of the bill for government services.

item.title: How Pandora Is Surviving Trump’s Trade War
item.description: Pandora, the Danish jewelry company, said it was “battle ready,” with plans to raise prices and reroute shipments from the United States, but tariffs could potentially cost it millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers in a Pandora jewelry store at the American Dream mall in East Rutherford, N.J. The company, best known for its silver charm bracelets, has been making jewelry in Thailand since 1989.

item.title: Carvana, a Used Car Retailer, Thinks Tariffs Could be Good for Business
item.description: The chief executive of Carvana, which sells used cars online, said President Trump’s tariffs could help his company by increasing demand for its vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Carvana, an online seller of used cars, sees opportunity in high tariffs because it expects demand for used cars to climb.

item.title: Is Slate Auto’s Electric Truck the Answer to Expensive Cars?
item.description: Slate Auto, a start-up backed by Jeff Bezos, plans to sell a small, spartan electric truck that comes with no paint, stereo or touch-screens.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence Ulrich

category.#text: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A model truck at Slate Auto’s design center in Troy, Mich. The company is backed by venture capital firms and Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder.

item.title: CPI Report Shows Inflation Cooled in April Ahead of Likely Jump From Tariffs
item.description: Economists and policymakers are bracing for inflation to re-accelerate as companies adapt to President Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:description: Economists predict that U.S. consumers will face higher costs because of tariffs.

item.title: Jerome Powell, a Potential Winner from the Trade Reprieve
item.description: The markets have come around to the Federal Reserve chairman’s cautious approach to lowering interest rates. President Trump could be a tougher convert.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
item.media:description: Investors and economists have suddenly come around to Jay Powell’s wait-and-see stance on interest rates.

item.title: U.S. Could Lose $12.5 Billion In International Travel Spending This Year, Tourism Council Says
item.description: Border detentions and confusion over visas are deterring international visitors, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council, and the price tag for their hesitancy could be steep.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States is on track to lose $12.5 billion in international travel spending this year, according to the latest Economic Impact Research published by the W.T.T.C. Above, travelers at Newark Liberty International Airport, in New Jersey, a major hub for international flights.

item.title: Tariff Misery in Japan: Honda and Nissan Forecast Plunges in Profit
item.description: Distress is spreading in Japan’s auto sector, putting into question Tokyo’s approach to trade negotiations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nissan’s global headquarters in Yokohama, Japan. The company suspended its profit forecast for this year.

item.title: A Toxic Pit Could Be a Gold Mine for Rare-Earth Elements
item.description: Mining continues at the Continental Pit. Nearby is the Berkeley Pit, a site for acid mine drainage that poses an opportunity for extracting valuable metals.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

category.#text: Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: German Companies Grow Wary of Investing in the U.S.
item.description: German companies invest more than three times as much in the United States as American companies do in Germany, but they are starting to rethink that strategy.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: German companies have been producing goods in the United States since the late 1800s, but recent surveys indicate that German manufacturers are pulling back from investing in America.

item.title: There Are Two Chinas, and America Must Understand Both
item.description: The technological success that has captured the attention of many in the United States is one aspect of the Chinese economy. There’s another, gloomy one.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: With Guarantees Galore, Christie’s Has a Rocky Start to Auction Week
item.description: There was little excited bidding on the art collection of the Riggio family, who built their fortune on the Barnes & Noble bookstore chain — a caution flag for the art market.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Tim F. Schneider

item.title: Elon Musk’s Boring Company Is in Talks With Government Over Amtrak Project
item.description: The Federal Railroad Administration has brought in the tunneling company to see if it could help with a multibillion-dollar rail project.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Mark Walker
item.media:description: The Boring Company facility in Bastrop, Texas. The Federal Railroad Administration has brought in the tunneling firm, founded by Elon Musk, to help with a multibillion-dollar Amtrak project.

item.title: ‘MAGA Accounts’ and No Tax on Tips: Republicans Plan to Inject Trump Into Tax Code
item.description: House Republicans on Monday outlined their plans for a far-reaching tax bill that would deliver on several of President Trump’s campaign pledges — for now.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:description: The tax legislation proposed by House Republicans would temporarily enact several of President Trump’s campaign pledges.

item.title: Trump’s China Deal Frees Up Shipping. Will Goods Pour Into the U.S.?
item.description: The temporary lowering of tariffs may compel some U.S. businesses to order goods that they had held off buying after President Trump raised them to 145 percent.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis and Danielle Kaye
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Experts say whiplash tariff policies are piling stress onto the companies that transport goods around the world.

item.title: Hollywood Groups Call for Tax Changes After Trump’s Tariff Threat
item.description: “Returning more production to the United States will require a national approach and broad-based policy solutions,” the groups said in a letter  to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: The Motion Picture Association asked for a range of tax breaks in a letter it and several other groups sent to President Trump.

item.title: Tariff Truce With China Demonstrates the Limits of Trump’s Aggression
item.description: President Trump’s triple-digit tariffs on Chinese products disrupted global trade — but haven’t appeared to result in major concessions from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: The tariffs on Chinese goods ultimately proved too painful to American businesses for President Trump to sustain.

item.title: Trump Administration Considers Large Chip Sale to Emirati A.I. Firm G42
item.description: The firm, which the U.S. government scrutinized for its ties to China, is angling for hundreds of thousands of advanced artificial intelligence chips in a deal that could be finalized this week.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s artificial intelligence czar, David Sacks, right, has been negotiating a deal that could send U.S.-designed A.I. chips to an Emirati company.

item.title: Fox to Launch New Streaming Service, Fox One, This Fall
item.description: The new service will combine the company’s TV shows, cable channels and broadcast network, including National Football League games.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin
item.media:description: The Fox Nation streaming service will continue to exist as a stand-alone product within Fox Corporation, but Fox One subscribers will be able to bundle their subscriptions with Fox Nation.

item.title: Trump Family Bitcoin Company Announces Plan to Go Public
item.description: American Bitcoin, a cryptocurrency firm co-founded by Eric Trump, said it was merging with a company traded on the Nasdaq, the latest expansion of the family’s investments in crypto.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An attendee at a Bitcoin conference in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, last year.

item.title: Fed Official Still Bracing for Economic Slowdown Despite China Tariff Pause
item.description: Austan D. Goolsbee, president of the Chicago Fed, said there was still a risk of higher consumer prices and slower growth amid elevated uncertainty about the White House’s trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tariffs and the uncertainty about President Trump’s trade policies could cause higher prices and slower growth, a Federal Reserve official warned on Monday.

item.title: Newark Airport Air Traffic Staffing Shortage Forces Delays
item.description: The shortage on Monday forced the F.A.A. to delay flights to the busy airport for up to nearly seven hours, the latest problem to plague the airport.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi, Kate Kelly and Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newark Liberty International Airport has experienced a series of major delays in the past several days.

item.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Asking Companies to Lower Drug Prices
item.description: The president has long complained that the United States pays more for medicines than other wealthy countries. But he offered no clear legal authority to mandate lower prices.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: At an event Monday for his executive order, President Trump directed his ire toward European governments that have negotiated lower prices.

item.title: Avelo Airlines Faces Backlash for Aiding Trump’s Deportation Campaign
item.description: The company, which serves airports in liberal cities on the coasts, has agreed to operate chartered flights for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: The money that Avelo Airlines stands to make from deportation flights is too good to pass up, the company’s chief executive said last month in an internal email.

item.title: Robert Shapiro, Who Made NutraSweet a Household Name, Dies at 86
item.description: His promotion of the sugar substitute was a success. But later, as head of Monsanto, he faced blowback after the company rushed into genetically altered products.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Bill Stover for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert B. Shapiro in his office at Monsanto in 1999. He was named the company’s president in 1993 and chief executive in 1995, as Monsanto transitioned from mostly manufacturing chemicals to making drugs and genetically modified seeds, crops, fertilizer and food ingredients.

item.title: Inside the U.S.-China Trade Cease-Fire
item.description: Global markets are rallying on optimism over Washington and Beijing reaching a major, if temporary, détente in their tariff fight.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent this morning announced a major, though temporary, breakthrough in trade talks with China.

item.title: For Trump, It’s a New Era of Deal-Making With Tech’s Most-Coveted Commodity
item.description: As the president heads to the Middle East, America’s dominance over A.I. chips has become a powerful source of leverage for the president.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tripp Mickle
item.media:description: President Trump is touring the Middle East this week where he has strong business and financial ties. His administration appears to be interested in using artificial intelligence chips to secure strategic bonds in the region.

item.title: U.S. and China Reach Deal to Temporarily Slash Tariffs
item.description: The White House backed off from the steepest levies, as the costs of an all-out trade war with China threatened global economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Amy Chang Chien and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: The U.S. Treasury secretary, Scott Bessent, right, and the U.S. trade representative, Jamieson Greer, in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: Can the U.K.’s Military Spending Push Revive Its Small Towns, Too?
item.description: Britain is spending billions of pounds more on defense, but wants the money to go beyond nuclear submarines to improve local jobs and prosperity. Barrow-in-Furness may be the model.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The BAE factory, in the distance, looms over Barrow-in-Furness, England. Barrow has built Royal Navy vessels since the 1870s. Today, BAE employs about 14,500 people, offering the town’s most sought-after jobs.

item.title: US-China Tariff Pause Spurs Stock Market Surge
item.description: The S&P 500 logged its biggest gain in over a month after American and Chinese officials signaled a de-escalation in the trade war between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Jason Karaian
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, left, and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer led the U.S. delegation to the talks in Geneva. Mr. Bessent said there had been “substantial progress.”

item.title: Trump Plan Would Tie Some Drug Prices to What Peer Nations Pay
item.description: The president announced an executive order aimed at lowering U.S. drug costs, revisiting an idea that was blocked in court during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:description: President Trump, flanked by Jay Bhattacharya, director of the National Institutes of Health, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the Health and Human Services secretary, during another executive order signing ceremony last week.

item.title: Why Patients Are Being Forced to Switch to a 2nd-Choice Obesity Drug
item.description: CVS Caremark decided to stop offering Zepbound in favor of Wegovy for weight loss. It’s the latest example of limits imposed by insurance that disrupt treatments for patients.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Reed Abelson
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: An injection pen for Zepbound, which Caremark intends to stop offering in July.

item.title: 130,000 Igloo Coolers Recalled After Fingertip Amputations From Handle
item.description: The warning expands a recall of more than one million Igloo coolers in February, which was prompted by reports of fingertip injuries from the tow handle.
item.dc:creator: Sara Ruberg
item.media:credit: via United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
item.media:description: The tow handle of the Igloo cooler has pinched customers’ fingertips and caused severe injuries, a federal safety agency said.

item.title: A Shipping Change Might Help Small Businesses if Not for Trump’s Trade Wars
item.description: Companies squeezed by Shein and Temu are welcoming the end of a shipping rule that bolstered the Chinese e-commerce giants. But broader tariff concerns are outweighing any optimism.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kaye
item.media:credit: Mohamed Sadek for The New York Times

item.title: The Tech Guys Are Fighting. Literally.
item.description: Not content to battle it out in the boardroom, crypto bros, tech executives and start-up founders have embraced an old-fashioned version of masculinity.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew DeFeo
item.media:description: Andrew Batey, a venture capitalist, went to the annual cryptocurrency conference in Denver not to network with fellow crypto enthusiasts but to fight one of them.

item.title: U.S. Says ‘Substantial Progress’ Made in Trade Talks With China
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the details would be announced on Monday after two days of negotiations in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Members of the Chinese delegation at the trade talks in Geneva.

item.title: Why America’s ‘Beautiful Beef’ Is a Trade War Sore Point for Europe
item.description: European officials call food safety standards a “red line,” as Trump administration officials criticize rules that keep American beef and other meats off grocery shelves.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hendrik Dierendonck, right, and one of his chefs, Timon Michiels, at work at his butchery and restaurant in Saint-Idesbald, Belgium, last month.

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes’s Partner Has a New Blood-Testing Start-Up
item.description: Billy Evans has two children with the Theranos founder, who is in prison for fraud. He’s now trying to raise money for a testing company that promises “human health optimization.”
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Billy Evans with his partner, Elizabeth Holmes, at their home in 2023.

item.title: ‘Don’t Need a Deal’: Top Trump Economic Adviser Is All In on His China Hardball
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview, Stephen Miran, the chair of President Trump’s Council of Economic Advisers, said, “Volatility doesn’t necessarily mean anything greater for the long term.”
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.media:description: Stephen Miran is President Trump’s top economic adviser.

item.title: Worried About the Economy Amid Trump’s Tariffs? Building an Emergency Fund Can Help.
item.description: One bit of advice: Putting aside $2,000 to cover surprise expenses, like a car or home repair, can help you avoid credit cards. Experts have more tips on saving.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: How Much Do People Pay for Newsletters Like Substack? It Can Be Surprising.
item.description: More people are spending money on newsletters from their favorite writers. They’re also having trouble keeping track of how many they subscribe to.
item.dc:creator: Logan Sachon

item.title: ‘Sinners’ Box Office Success Could Put It in Hollywood’s Horror Hall of Fame
item.description: The horror movie from Ryan Coogler is on a pace to collect at least $330 million in worldwide ticket sales, a level reached by few original films in the genre.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:description: Michael B. Jordan in “Sinners,” which could become the biggest original horror movie since “A Quiet Place” in 2018.

item.title: Remarrying in Retirement Can Mean Tricky Money Talks
item.description: People over 65 who remarry after a death or divorce can face thorny financial questions — especially when it comes to adult children and inheritances.
item.dc:creator: Martha C. White
item.media:credit: Benjamin Cleeton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elaina Clapper had been divorced for about 40 years when she remarried, to her husband David. “We just kind of talked about what we were both bringing to the marriage financially,” she said.

item.title: US and China Meet for First Time Since Trump Imposed Tariffs
item.description: The outcome of the trade negotiations, which will continue on Sunday, could determine the trajectory of the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Ana Swanson and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is leading the American side in the negotiations with China, which began Saturday and continue Sunday.

item.title: With U.S. Trade Deal, UK Steel Industry Feels Some Much Needed Relief
item.description: The agreement to lift the 25 percent duty on steel exported to the United States provided some relief for struggling businesses, but uncertainties for the industry remain.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Owen Richards for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcegaglia’s cavernous plant in Sheffield, England.

item.title: Chinese Factories Are Moving Manufacturing to Vietnam to Escape Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: A movement of manufacturing to Vietnam that began in President Trump’s first term is accelerating as sky-high U.S. tariffs block Chinese exports.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: As orders become impossible to fulfill in China with tariffs of more than 145 percent, Chinese companies are trying to move manufacturing to Vietnam.

item.title: U.S. Starts Investigation Into Imported Planes and Parts
item.description: The Trump administration could use the investigation to impose new tariffs on imported planes, jet engines and other aerospace parts.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Lindsey Wasson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Boeing factory in Everett, Wash. An investigation by the Trump administration into imports of jet engines and other aviation parts could be the first step in the imposition of tariffs on those products.

item.title: Robert A.G. Monks, Crusader Against ‘Imperial’ C.E.O.s, Dies at 91
item.description: A descendant of American wealth, he used his success in business to push for social responsibility in corporate leadership and encouraged shareholders to push back.
item.dc:creator: James R. Hagerty
item.media:credit: Craig Dilger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert A.G. Monks, at his home in Cape Elizabeth, Maine, in May 2013. Partly as a result of his efforts and those of like-minded activists, more companies separated the jobs of chairman and chief executive, which had often been held by the same person.
